title: 108_hr623
content: The Act titled "Medical Laboratory Personnel Shortage Act of 2003" addresses the shortage of medical laboratory personnel through programs administered by the Health Resources and Services Administration. The "Medical Laboratory Personnel Shortage Act of 2003" addresses the shortage of medical laboratory personnel through scholarship and loan repayment programs for medical technologists, medical laboratory technicians, and other medical laboratory personnel in designated shortage areas. Eligible entities include schools of allied health. Eligible entities for awards under the "Medical Laboratory Personnel Shortage Act of 2003" include schools of allied health and health care institution-based programs training medical laboratory personnel. Authorization of appropriations is set at $11,193,000 for fiscal year 2004, with additional funding for fiscal years 2005 through 2008. Other programs under Title VII provide preference in making awards and public service announcements for allied health and other disciplines. The "Medical Laboratory Personnel Shortage Act of 2003" gives preference in making awards to entities expanding programs to increase trained medical laboratory personnel. The Secretary will develop public service announcements promoting careers in this field. Authorization of appropriations is set at $11,193,000 for fiscal year 2004, with additional funding for fiscal years 2005 through 2008. The "Medical Laboratory Personnel Shortage Act of 2003" authorizes $100,000,000 for fiscal year 2004 and additional funding for fiscal years 2005 through 2008 for allied health and other disciplines. Section 740 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include subsection (d) for medical laboratory personnel training grants or contracts. Authorized appropriations for grants or contracts under sections 737 through 739 for schools of allied health include $332,500 for faculty awards in fiscal year 2004 and additional funding for years 2005 through 2008. For awards to schools, $8,200,000 is allocated for fiscal year 2004 and additional funding for years 2005 through 2008. The definition of medical laboratory personnel is expanded in Section 799B of the Public Health Service Act. The term 'medical laboratory personnel' includes allied health professionals who examine materials from the human body for diagnostic purposes. SEC. 1509A addresses the shortage of technologists for laboratory analysis related to cervical cancer screening. The Secretary will make grants to entities to train cytotechnologists for cervical cancer screening. $10,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2004, with additional funding for 2005-2008. The Secretary will make grants for training cytotechnologists for cervical cancer screening, with $10,000,000 authorized for fiscal year 2004 and additional funding for 2005-2008, unless the appropriation is at least $173,928,000. The amendment to the Public Health Service Act emphasizes training medical laboratory personnel in disciplines with increased personnel needs.
